_metadata.description: Microscopy equipment knowledge base for MicroHub pipeline. Maps microscope models to brands, software, techniques, lasers, and detectors for tag inference and validation.
sources: Manufacturer product pages (Zeiss, Leica, Nikon, Olympus/Evident)

systems.notes: Flagship confocal with Airyscan 2 multiplex for 4x/8x faster super-res
Compact confocal with Airyscan 2, smaller footprint than LSM 980
First Airyscan system; NLO option for multiphoton
Entry-level confocal with Airyscan
QUASAR 34-channel spectral detector; NLO multiphoton option
Spectral detection introduced in this generation
Solid-state laser-only compact confocal
Long-lived workhorse; META variant had spectral detector
Lattice SIM with optical sectioning; combines SIM + SMLM + TIRF
First-gen SIM/PALM/STORM platform
Tilt illumination with pivot scanning
First commercial dual-illumination light sheet
Automated box microscope; optional LSM 900 or spinning disk add-on
Inverted research microscope platform; base for LSM and spinning disk
Upright research microscope for pathology, neuroscience, materials
Legacy inverted platform; widely referenced in older literature
Legacy upright; very common in older papers
Current flagship; White Light Laser (WLL) for tunable excitation 440-790nm; FLIM built-in
Modular platform with many variants: STED 3X, FALCON (FLIM), DIVE (multiphoton), LIGHTNING (decon)
Introduced HyD detectors; widely deployed, huge install base

objectives: HC PL APO 100x/1.40 OIL STED WHITE
systems.notes: 3D STED with depletion lasers at 592, 660 and 775nm
Computational clearing (instant deconvolution) for widefield
Inverted platform; base for SP8/Stellaris, STED, TIRF
Upright automated research microscope
Current flagship with 8K resonant scanning; NSPARC for super-res
R variant has resonant scanner for fast imaging
Entry-level confocal; C2si variant has spectral imaging
N-SIM S has high-speed SIM; combines with STORM
Combines with N-SIM for multimodal super-res
25mm FOV inverted platform; base for A1/AX, N-SIM, N-STORM, CSU spinning disk
Hugely popular inverted platform; Ti-E = fully motorized
RS variant has resonant+galvano dual scanner; TruSpectral detection
SIM scanner for simultaneous stimulation/imaging
Enormous install base; still widely referenced
Fully motorized inverted; base for confocal, spinning disk, TIRF
Semi-motorized inverted; more affordable than IX83
Motorized upright for histology and fluorescence
Spinning disk with optical super-resolution (SoRa technology)
Slide scanner for whole-slide imaging
Dual spinning disk (50µm and 25µm pinholes); SoRa super-res option; mounted on host microscope body
Most widely deployed spinning disk; 5000rpm or 10000rpm
Compact STED module that attaches to existing microscope body
Dedicated STED system with pulsed STED at 775nm; MINFLUX option
Multi-view SPIM for developmental biology
Optimized for cleared tissue imaging (CLARITY, iDISCO, CUBIC, etc)
Turnkey imaging system; typically Zeiss Axio Observer base
Open-source mesoscale SPIM for cleared tissue
Dual-view inverted SPIM by ASI; isotropic resolution via dual-view fusion
Open-source light sheet build; parts list and wiki at openspim.org
Automated whole-organ imaging of cleared tissue
Gold standard for cryo-EM SPA; 300kV; autoloader
200kV cryo-EM for screening and data collection
200kV; Arctica for cryo-EM, L120C for room-temperature TEM
Workhorse TEM; Spirit at 120kV, F20 at 200kV, F30 at 300kV

techniques: Focused Ion Beam Scanning Electron Microscopy
systems.notes: Dual-beam FIB-SEM for serial sectioning and cryo-FIB
120kV TEM; Flash variant for cryo screening
200kV analytical TEM
Cold FEG cryo-EM; competitor to Titan Krios
High-content confocal plate imager; Harmony for analysis
Automated multiwell plate imaging; Confocal variant has spinning disk
Requires tunable fs laser (e.g., Coherent Chameleon, Spectra-Physics MaiTai/InSight)
Modular multiphoton platform for in vivo neuroscience
Next-gen Olympus/Evident confocal with TruResolution
Whole-slide imaging scanner for digital pathology
Widely used clinical/research slide scanner

Zeiss.notes: ZEN Blue = newer, ZEN Black = legacy LSM systems

Leica.notes: LAS X replaced LAS AF circa 2015

Nikon.notes: C = confocal module, AR = advanced research

Olympus.notes: FluoView for confocal, cellSens for widefield; Evident branding since 2022

Evident (Olympus).notes: Olympus life science division rebranded as Evident

Andor.notes: Andor cameras often controlled by host software (NIS, MetaMorph, etc)

Yokogawa.notes: Spinning disk unit controlled by host microscope software

PerkinElmer.notes: Harmony for Opera/Operetta; Volocity for older UltraVIEW

Molecular Devices.notes: MetaMorph was also widely used as generic acquisition software

Bruker.notes: Prairie Technologies acquired by Bruker; multiphoton systems

Abberior.notes: Imspector for all Abberior STED systems

FEI.notes: Now Thermo Fisher Scientific; EPU for cryo-EM automation

JEOL.notes: CRYO ARM systems use JADAS for automated acquisition

Hamamatsu.notes: Camera maker; NanoZoomer slide scanners use NDP software

laser_systems.notes: Most common multiphoton laser; Discovery NX has dual output
DeepSee variant has built-in GDD compensation
Compact multi-line laser; now HÜBNER Photonics
White light laser / supercontinuum; used in Leica WLL systems
